description: From Latin dithyrambus, from Ancient Greek δῑθύραμβος (dīthúrambos). According to the American Heritage Dictionary, it is of non-Indo-European origin (Pre-Greek substrate), related to θρίαμβος and ἴαμβος.  Brandenstein also compares Sanskrit अङ्ग (aṅga, “member”).

entries.meaning: A raucous and ardent  choral hymn sung in ancient Athens in honor of the god Dionysus.
A poem or oration in the same style.
examples: While those who drown a truth’s empiric part
In dithyramb or dogma turn frenetic;
— Than whom no writer could be less poetic
He left this lesson for all verse, all art.
